title: Veterinary Diagnosis: Senior Dog Symptoms
hint: An endocrine disorder common in older dogs

clues.text: Excessive thirst and urination (polydipsia and polyuria)
clues.explanation: Elevated cortisol levels interfere with the kidneys' ability to concentrate urine, leading to increased water consumption and urination.
Chronic cortisol excess causes redistribution of fat to the abdomen and weakening of abdominal muscles, creating a characteristic sagging belly.

clues.text: Bilateral symmetrical hair loss and thin skin
clues.explanation: Excess cortisol inhibits hair follicle growth and causes skin atrophy, resulting in thinning fur on both sides of the body and paper-thin skin.
High cortisol levels affect respiratory control and muscle weakness in the diaphragm, causing persistent panting.

clues.text: Elevated alkaline phosphatase on chemistry panel
clues.explanation: Cortisol induces a specific liver enzyme (steroid-induced ALP), which dramatically elevates on blood chemistry tests.

clues.text: Enlarged adrenal glands visible on ultrasound
clues.explanation: The disease causes either pituitary-dependent bilateral adrenal enlargement or a unilateral adrenal tumor, both visible on abdominal ultrasound.
